body.p: There are two traffic lights on Fred’s route from home to work. Over the years Fred has tracked when he has to stop at these lights. He determined that 45% of the time he has to stop at the first light; 30% of the time he has to stop at the second light, and 20% of the time he has to stop at both lights.

Let A be the event that Fred has to stop at the first light. Let B be the event that Fred has to stop at the second light. What is the probability that Fred has to stop at one or more lights on his way to work?

response.feedback: Incorrect. You may have used the General Addition Rule P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A and B) but calculated P(A and B) incorrectly by multiplying P(A) * P(B). This is incorrect because A and B are not independent in this situation. P(A and B) is given as 0.20, which is not equal to P(A) * P(B) = 0.45 * 0.30 = 0.135.
Correct. P(at least one stop) = P(A or B). Since the events are not disjoint, we must use the General Addition Rule. P(A or B) = 0.45 + 0.30 − 0.20 = 0.55
Incorrect. P(at least one stop) = P(A or B) but the events are not disjoint. So P (A or B) is not equal to P(A) + P(B). You need to use the General Addition Rule.

Incorrect. Adding all three probabilities is incorrect since P(A) = 0.45 and P(B) = 0.30 both include the situation in which Fred stops at both lights. So P(A and B) = 0.20 has to be subtracted as shown in the General Addition Rule.

part.hint: The event “stop at one or more lights” is equivalent to “stop at at least one light.” In other words, you need to find the probability that Fred stops at the first light or the second light or both, which is P(A or B).
